etymology.description: Ideogrammic: 丂 (“fork in a tree”) + two parallel vertical strokes above (finer branches; sound of wind); originally the same as 乎.
etymology.interpretation: Imagery of a branching trunk with twigs evokes wind passing through branches, yielding an exclamatory sound. It later became a sentence-final particle expressing emotion or emphasis in Classical Chinese.

examples.chinese: 美人兮(美人兮)，见之不忘(見之不忘)。
examples.pinyin: měi rén xī, jiàn zhī bù wàng.
examples.english: Fair beauty—upon seeing her, one does not forget.

examples.chinese: 山高兮(山高兮)，水长(水長)。
examples.english: High are the mountains; the waters run long.

examples.chinese: 吾心伤兮(吾心傷兮)，泪下如雨(淚下如雨)。
examples.pinyin: wú xīn shāng xī, lèi xià rú yǔ.
examples.english: My heart aches; tears fall like rain.
